Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Can Evolutionary History Predict How Changes in Biodiversity Impact the Productivity of Ecosystems?
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientists seek to understand how the current accelerating loss of biodiversity will affect the productivity and sustainability of Earth's ecosystems. The goal of this project is to predict which species extinctions will have the greatest effect on primary production, the fundamentally important process of photosynthetic capture of biomass. This project tests the novel hypothesis that evolution leads to genetic divergence and niche differences among species. In turn, niche differences lead to a 'division of labor' that determines how efficiently biological communities capture the limited resources needed to produce new biomass. To test this hypothesis, the project bridges the fields of ecology, phylogenetics, and genomics to examine how one of the most widespread and ecologically important groups of algae impacts the productivity of lakes throughout North America. The goals are to 1) Create a new molecular phylogeny that can be used to test whether assemblages of freshwater algae are more genetically diverse than expected by chance. 2) Experimentally manipulate the evolutionary and genetic divergence of species to assess how these aspects of biodiversity control niche differences and primary production. 3) Conduct analyses of gene expression data to identify the genetic basis of niche differences among species, and relate these to rates of primary production by phytoplankton communities.

The project will train a variety of students from high school interns to postdoctoral researchers in multidisciplinary work blending genomics, phylogenetics, and ecology. Two K-12 exercises will broaden students' appreciation for biological diversity in important freshwater habitats. The information from the project will provide important information for the management of freshwater resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Based on our current understanding of the universe, the only feature of our planet that is unique to Earth is its spectacular variety of life. An estimated 10 million species of multicellular plants and animals live on this planet, in addition to an unknown number of single celled bacteria. But while the spectacular variety of life is the most defining feature of our planet, loss of this biodiversity is one of the most pronounced forms of environmental change in the modern era. We live in an era where one-third to one-half of all known species may well be extinct within the next generation of human life. One of the primary goals of modern biology is to understand how species extinctions in the coming era will impact Earth’s ability to support human life, and to generate the goods and services needed to maintain healthy and prosperous societies.

 

The goal of this project was to predict which species extinctions will have the greatest impacts on primary production – an ecological process that is fundamentally important to the sustainability of all animal life on the planet. Primary production is the creation of new plant tissue. Production of plant tissue is important because it removes the greenhouse gas CO2 from the atmosphere, replaces it with life-giving oxygen and, in turn, produces food for nearly all animals.

 

Specifically, this project tested the hypothesis that the production of plant tissue is greatest among plant species that have developed genetic as well as ecological differences that allow them to specialize in their environment. When these specialist plants form diverse communities, a ‘division of labor’ among the plant species allows the community to capture more CO2 from the atmosphere, produce more oxygen, and more plant biomass that is potentially food for animals. To test this hypothesis, we used one of the most diverse groups of plants on Earth – green algae that inhabit lakes and oceans.

 

The results of our studies were remarkably consistent. We found that as species become more specialized in their environment, they do, in fact, exhibit a ‘division of labor’ that allows more diverse plant communities to take more CO2 out of the atmosphere, to produce more oxygen, and to make more plant tissue. From our studies, we were able to generate models that not only predict which species of plants are most important for protecting the production of plant tissue, but we were able to translate results these into economic models that help predict the value of species conservation for society.

 

Contrary to what we had expected, the division of labor among species was not predicted by genetic differences among species. It would appear that many of the mutations that lead to changes in genes among species do not impact what those species do ecologically in their environment. This also suggests that we cannot use genetic differences among species to predict the ecological consequences of species extinction for human society.

 

Our project produced a large number of scientific papers (23 peer-reviewed papers in top scientific journals) and research presentations (38 total) that informed other scientists about our studies. More importantly, the importance of our work for conservation, and the implication for protecting the goods and services that biodiversity provides to society, was distributed to the general public through syndicated news articles by Reuters, multiple radio interviews on National Public Radio, popular articles in numerous magazines, and an National Science Foundation press conference.

 

Lastly, our project helped train the next generation of our nation’s scientists by graduating 5 new master’s students, 2 postdoctoral scholars, and 8 undergraduate research assistants – nearly all of whom have gone on to productive careers in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM).
